description: This lecture course is designed to introduce the student to the functioning of the autonomic nervous system (ANS), which is critically involved in the maintenance of body homeostasis through regulation of behavior and physiology. The course will begin with a review of the basic anatomy and physiology of the ANS including the sympathetic, parasympathetic and enteric divisions. The mechanisms by which the ANS regulates peripheral tissues will be discussed, including reflex and regulatory functions, as will the effect of drugs which modulate ANS activity. The role of the ANS in regulating behavior will be addressed in the context of thirst, salt appetite and food intake.
name: AUTONOMIC PHYSIOLOGY

values.comments:
This lecture course is designed to introduce the student to the functioning of the
autonomic nervous system (ANS), which is critically involved in the maintenance of
body homeostasis through regulation of behavior and physiology. The course begins with
a review of the basic anatomy and physiology of the ANS including the sympathetic,
parasympathetic and enteric divisions. The mechanisms by which the ANS regulates
peripheral tissues are discussed, including reflex and regulatory functions, as are the
effect of drugs, which modulate ANS activity. The role of the ANS in regulating behavior
is addressed in the context of thirst, salt appetite and food intake.
Students reported that they “learned a lot from the course” and that the material
was enjoyable. Students also wrote that BIBB 269 was one of their favorite courses at
Penn.
Students really liked Professor Heerding, describing her as an “excellent
professor” who explained things very well. She was very engaging and was able to “tie
in stories about patients, studies, and specific drugs” very effectively. One student did
mention that Professor Heerding was not easily accessible outside of class; although,
another wrote that Heerding was the best professor he has had at Penn.
While students spoke favorably of the material, the course involved “a lot of
information and required a lot of time to memorize.” One student also mentioned that
exams could be “confusing” and “tricky.” Another suggested that it is “great for pre-med
students to take this class, but probably not otherwise.”
*Only eight students submitted reviews for this course.
